choices: Audrey Durant (26) the tall, blonde, bespeckled over-stressed head of house
Reagan Durant (22) the conniving and rambunctious redheaded twin
Phoebe Durant (22) the naïve and ditzy redheaded twin
Ixchel Park (23) the mixed raced nerdy cousin
Uma Ferro (25) the strong, black, hedonistic former athlete
1.content:
The townhouse at 8422 Fordham Ave had a lot going for it. It sat at the alley break between two townhouse blocks, a split-level three story home plus a basement access garage. Having only one neighbor on the west wall allowed for a unique interior, with the living/dining room having an elevated ceiling with overhanging second floor balcony. The kitchen had a breakfast nook that jutted towards the alley and the front yard was marginally wider by three feet.

As far as locations went you couldn’t get better in the city. Being at the corner of Fordham Ave and 11th Court placed it two blocks down from the dining district. Most of the area townhomes were quaint, red brick and copper color trim affairs. The interior of 8422 used peach, orange and beige accents along most walls.

Going from the bottom up, the basement included a single car garage, laundry room and small den. On the ground floor was the main entrance, kitchen, dining table and living room. The second floor contained two small bedrooms and a short office. The third floor contained the master suite and another small room that had been converted into a bedroom. Each floor also had a bathroom to some capacity.

While the home had a lot going for it vertically, horizontally it left a lot to be desired. Despite the small floor space the house was the definitive model modern townhome that provided some luxury but only for a renting couple or small family.

8422 Fordham Ave had not been designed to have five residents. Yet five women ended up living there.

The original tenants were the Durant sisters; the oldest, Audrey and her twin sisters Reagan and Phoebe. Audrey was the first to look for the listing but couldn’t afford the price solely and agreed to let her sisters live there, who were still in university downtown. Before long not only was the Durant sisters’ cousin, Ixchel Park, asking to move in but Audrey’s former college roommate, Uma Ferro, had needed a place to crash. That was two years ago.

These five ladies were quite different people but had more or less gotten used to living together.

Audrey Durant was the oldest occupant at 26. She was also the tallest, the primary breadwinner and the most serious much to her chagrin, as she felt she had to take care of everything. She wore glasses for green-eyed farsightedness and had a copious amount of bushy blond hair, much like a decades old fashion trend. She was fair skinned with the occasional freckle. Although she stood two heads taller than her twin sisters she never really had a thin physique growing up. It was kind to call her chubby or plump as her body settled into an apple shape.

When she wasn’t stressing herself out with earning money to pay for bills, getting to work on time and keeping the house afloat she had mildly antiquated interests. She liked her sappy romance novels and the chance to have a bubble bath, she preferred the stage compared to the movies for theater and she had attempted to keep a garden in the front yard as she knew a lot about flowers. Although she could get easily riled up as most of her other housemates found most of her tastes boring.

Reagan and Phoebe, the identical twin Durant sisters, of course had matching features. While some of their facial features and skin tone matched Audrey their physiques were quite different. At 22 the twins were just under the average height for an American woman, with slender necks and small shoulders. Both had reddish hair with naturally blonde highlights. Both were hip heavy, having developed wide hipped pear shapes in late middle school. As they grew older the twins had a pair of fine booties to match, making them very attractive and popular but for vastly different reasons once you got to know their personalities.

Reagan was the oldest twin by two seconds. She was fierce, mischievous and very standout. If you called her the evil twin she would wear the moniker with pride. She was too clever by a half when it came to nearly flunking out of school because of an academic career of getting associated with trouble but (thus far) she was still working on her acoustical engineering degree. Yet her penchant for calling others out and wanting to have the last laugh or last insult at all times often left her with her foot in her mouth. She also wasn’t brilliant by any means, although she foolishly though herself smart, getting by from guile alone. She’d had plenty of boyfriends and left plenty of broken hearts along the way.

Phoebe was the youngest twin by two seconds. She was very much the baby of the family, bubbly but naïve and way too much of a ditz. While she was kind and friendly she was far too gullible for her own good, such was the case with being the good twin. She was also prone to klutziness and generally making a mess of things despite her best efforts. Her simple mind meant there wasn’t a conceited bone in her body, although some found her blind optimism a bit grating after awhile. She was looking to get into modeling and was pursuing an acting degree from the same university as her sister. She’d had plenty of boyfriends and suitors over the years but was a hopeless smitten kitten that couldn’t tell a decent boyfriend apart from a jerk.

Telling the twins apart came down to their body language, fashion, and attitude. Reagan favored darker colors and often kept her hair just shorter than her twin, while Phoebe favored brighter colors and was the girly-est of the duo.

The next closest relation to the Durant women was their cousin Ixchel Park, who also went by Chel. While the Durants had a mix of Euro-Caucasian ancestry Ixchel was the offspring of a multiracial marriage. About 43% of her genomes came from Central and South American while 39% was Asian by way of Korea with a smattering of Chinese, with mixed American and European as the remaining slurry. Despite her origins as a child of her mother’s second marriage she was closer to her Durant cousins than her multiracial relatives, as they were of the same generation and had spent quite a lot of their childhoods together.

Ixchel was 23, the second youngest of the household not accounting for the twins, with dark skin, grey eyes and long deeply dark brown hair. Her genetics left her moon faced and somewhat pudgy, as her body was entirely made up of rounded curves. While she had an even balance of introverted and extroverted tendencies she preferred the company of family and friends she already knew. Ixchel was very nerdy, both a band geek and a pop-culture obsessed otaku who used the cramped office for remote working in her programming job for a medical-tech company. She liked a lot of genres from fantasy to sci-fi to mysteries. And although she was loath to admit it, she had inherited a bit of cooking skill from her biracial father and had an index of Mexican and Asian fused dishes.

The only occupant not to be related by blood or family was Uma Ferro, Audrey’s roommate in college. Both had attended on scholarship but whereas Audrey’s was academic Uma had been under a sports scholarship. Uma was 25, black, and thickly built, voluptuous with athletic muscle mass. She had hazel eyes and liked to bleach the tips of her dreadlocks. Originally she had been a long distance track runner in high school, before drifting to lacrosse and her volleyball scholarship. Although a strong competitor she had yet to break into any big leagues, mainly for two reasons.

Uma could have a gruff, almost abrasive personality towards any perceived opponents. But mostly she was a raucous partier ever since college, being primarily responsible for helping Audrey get out of her shell. Uma never met a drink she didn’t like, a party favor she didn’t want seconds of and a groove she couldn’t drop a beat too. She’d grown wilder during college, looking for fun even if that meant her grades or training diligence suffered for it. At her worst, Uma could be considered a moocher since coming to live with the other women of the house. She didn’t have a steady job or a reason to return to school and while she trained constantly (or so she claimed) she no longer had a clear goal in mind to shape her drive. Her appetite was something fierce, the product of when her metabolism was hyperactive to fuel her adequately for all her team sports.


Altogether, while the female residents of 8422 Fordham Ave came from various walks of life and had such differing perspectives, they wouldn’t still be living together if they didn’t like each other. They got along fine; although like many families especially for an arrangement of twenty-something adults there were plenty of disagreements, outbursts and drama on any given day. Nobody ever got the privacy they hoped for with a townhouse that small, as each woman’s sheer force of personality, lifestyle, and the baggage that came with it left the house stuffed to the gills enough already.

And that was before they all got really freakin’ fat.

Pick a focal character:
1.title: Introducing the Five

choices: She was neck deep in chores, as usual.
She had to get out the door to get to work on time.
There’s plenty of ruckus brewing in the townhouse.
Audrey needed to get ready for a date.
The stress drives Audrey to eat, and eat she does.
11.content:
The past few years had almost made Audrey Durant snap.

Although she had been close to her sisters and cousin when they were kids that was back when, as the oldest, she could maintain her authority from age alone. Back before they lived together as adults. Audrey had thought they would be fine on sharing rent, after all they were family. That was before she realized that sisters were meant to go out into the world on their own after they grew up.

She really wished they would go out.

Her sisters were just horrendous, treating her like she was mom. They were adults that could pick up behind themselves and do something with their lives. Maybe, just maybe, Audrey hoped, Reagan and Phoebe would get somewhere in life once they completed college. But their combined work ethic left little to stoke these hopes.

Her cousin Ixchel was practically a saint compared to the twins. She actually had a steady job and contributed to rent. While she wasn’t out to make Audrey’s life miserable she had gotten far too cozy at the townhouse. For all her genius she could be a bit of a scatterbrain sometimes. Audrey found all of Ixchel’s favorite books and movies mixed up in places they shouldn’t be. Ixchel could get tunnel focused when she was working on a difficult problem, tuning out the rest of the world and barging in unannounced.

And then there was Uma. Audrey may have caved in too easily when Uma needed a place to stay but she was her best friend. Audrey had to mature quickly, being the oldest of three girls, and it was Uma who had taught her how to have fun again. Once having an outsider’s perspective, it was Uma who kept Audrey’s spirits lifted through life’s little challenges. Yet she had a knack for never volunteering and avoiding most of the work. This living arrangement was starting to feel one sided, with Uma being all take and no give. That was before Audrey factored in the foibles of five women living together.

When was the last time she could have a private bubble bath? Audrey couldn’t remember. The townhouse’s three bathrooms and five residents meant there was always going to be inconvenient overlap when trying to freshen up. Sometimes it was Ixchel barging in, as mentioned before, watching a gaming stream on her phone or listening to her work boosting music. Or it was Phoebe forgetting about closed-door policy, yet again, even if she apologized for it and could Audrey please pass her the deodorant?

Or Audrey never got to use the bathroom whenever Uma was washing off her post workout sweat or Reagan inconsiderately ignored every knock on the door to hurry up because get off her back, she was still getting ready.

Even when Audrey got a chance to take a break she could still hear whatever her roommates were up to thanks to the thin walls of the house. Plus, to add insult to injury, there were the constant cracks about her weight.

Audrey hadn’t always been fat but being naturally big boned and tall she had never really been thin either. She was the frumpy, dumpy shaped older daughter who filled out too much where the twins were blessed with hot bods. Audrey’s blonde hair always got out of her control. Her budget was stretched thin so she rarely got new clothes, so most of her apparel was getting frayed and a midge snug. When she wasn’t finding it lost in someone else’s hamper.

As she cleaned her glasses, Audrey felt like she wasn’t living her own life. Everyone left her to do most things. She was far too pragmatic for her own good, as her roommates had become accustomed to Audrey handling the bills and domestic needs. When was she going to have the chance to live her own life?

It turned out it was going to be another stressed out day for poor Audrey.
11.title: Audrey Durant

choices: It was laundry day and there was plenty to sort out.
Audrey had to go grocery shopping.
There were dirty dishes and spent wrappers all over the townhouse.
The mother of all messes had been left in the fridge.
111.content:
Audrey didn't know when she had let her guard down. She had laid down what she believed to be fair and basic house rules for everyone when the moved in. A rotating schedule where everyone pitched in on short, simple tasks one or two days a week.

Yet two years on and most of the chores had been left to Audrey. Just because she was the oldest shouldn't mean she had to be the only one who took this seriously.

Although Phoebe had been hopeless when it came to even the most basic of chores. Uma and Reagan could shirk out of duties like nobody's business. As in, nobody did the household business. Even Ixchel could be tied up with her job, which was frustrating for Audrey because her cousin could work from the townhouse, couldn't she take a moment to lend her a hand?

It didn't help the Audrey needed to go shopping for new clothes but sadly she couldn't prioritize that on her task list.

Audrey's clothes showed signs of having seen better days. Her patterned leggings were quite stretched and her white top had some ground in stains that couldn't get removed. It was the only clean pair of clothes she had that weren't old and raggy.

The underwire of her bra was also digging into her side, which didn't improve Audrey's mood. It was added irritation to all she had to do today. She just had to buckle down and grunt it out to get these chores done.
111.title: Chores, Chores, Chores

choices: Ixchel’s shirts are stretched out and her pants have gone up a size.
The twins used to share everything but now their weights are out of whack.
Uma’s gym clothes sit unused while her sport bras have busted.
Unfortunately for Audrey, her own clothes are smaller than she remembered.
1111.content:
“Pigs keep a cleaner sty than this!”

Audrey was neck deep in chores, a typical Thursday afternoon. She had mowed what little grass they had in the front yard, as the landlord was too cheap to have proper maintenance for the townhomes. Then she had been doing the dishes, during which she had asked each of dear sisters, cousin, and best friend to kindly get their laundry down the chute if they needed it washed. Audrey thought she had been clear. She shouldn’t have had to go searching for hampers. Nor been blessed with the column of week old laundry that had piled up below the chute, jamming it with a tower of soiled clothes.

“Everyone is so lucky that I do this!” Audrey fumed over the rumble of a dryer load as she scrubbed to work out stubborn stains before the pre-wash. She suddenly felt sorry of her parents when she and her sisters had been kids. Love meant learning about others more than you wanted too. You could get no worse of dirty laundry than dirty laundry and Audrey had seen all of it.

From Reagan’s skanky underwear to Phoebe’s childish throwbacks, to Ixchel’s mind-breaking shirts with references Audrey didn’t understand, to the unfortunate aftermath when Uma was going commando.

Laundry was once a week because it took Audrey that long to get the smell out of her mind. The combined odors of five women could be too much sometimes.

Audrey knew more about everyone’s fashion statements and intimates than she cared to, week after week of being the only one to do laundry. Well, that wasn’t fair. Phoebe had wanted to surprise her and finish the laundry before her older sister was forced to finish it.

Only that had left the colored dyes bleeding into the whites, bleach mixed in with the darks, Audrey’s favorite floral print shirt five sizes too small, and for days afterwards no pairs of socks could be partnered together.

So laundry was Audrey’s expertise. She knew the lifespan of every article of clothing from its date of purchase to when it finally gave up the ghost. It gave Audrey textile-based intel on each of her roommates. The double-duty dirty laundry.

Today, however, the laundry was painting Audrey a very different picture. From frayed ends and stretched seams, the telltale signs that one of the women in the house was gaining weight.
1111.title: Soiled Sundries

choices: Audrey is able to successfully buy some new clothes
House trouble brings Audrey back earlier than planned
11114.content:
Sighing with an air of frumpiness, Audrey begrudgingly pulled a rather stretched tank top from the machine and inspected it.
Biting her lip nervously, the stress prone blonde let her eyes survey the poor overworked garment, recognising it distinctly as hers but somewhat more bedraggled than even she liked to keep her clothes.

The plain white fabric assumed its usual array of stains and marks that came from Audrey's mundane daily routine of cleaning, cooking AND working to keep the townhouse afloat but other things were becoming apparent from the simple garment in her hands.

The printed pattern that adorned the general chest area had, as to be expected, suffered with age sporting cracks and fading from repeated washes of a t-shirt kept too long before been replaced, but it also showed signs of been stretched.
Lines that were once straight now bowed along their length whilst patches of colour had been spread so thinly in places that the white material underneath was visible.
Alongside the mutilated pattern, the hem of said shirt was also looking rather sorry for itself with a distinct wrinkling running the entire circumference of the shirt making clear indications that the material had been overtaxed and then shrunk back to its usual size from repeatative drying.

Audrey sighed again as she tossed the shirt into her basket of clean clothes ready to fold.
Sure, she didn't love the stretched garment excessively, she was more fond of the fact that it had fit her comfortably since starting college.
She'd even met Uma whilst wearing the damn thing.
The spark of memory brought a smile to the blonde's face as she remembered that night, grabbing the shirt again.

She was only a doey eyed freshman and had no friends but, all the same, found herself tottering around somebody's house party trying to mingle.
Entirely unsuccessful as she was no social butterfly like the twins were, Audrey eventually found an open door and staggered out into the open, gulping in fresh air to calm her nerves.
Feeling somewhat better for the rush of oxygen, Audrey found herself ready to return and hopefully make a friend or two.

That is, until she walked square into an unsuspecting guy smoking and took his tab square in the shoulder.

More from the shock than actual pain, Audrey had flown backwards, patting her shoulder with gusto in an attempt to put out a non-existent fire that had burnt a small hole in her shirt.
Oblivious once again, her flailing led her to crash into the back of who would later turn out to be Uma.

Laughing to herself with the memory swimming through her head, Audrey poked her finger through the now wider hole in the shoulder of her shirt.
A small portion of the hole retained its charred edge but most of it had disappeared as the mark widened over time.
Placated on the matter of the shirt, the dumpy blonde proceeded with sorting through laundry, for a short while at least.

"For god's sake" chuntered Audrey under her breath as she pulled a pair of leggings, also belonging to her, from the machine and inspected a rather unsightly line of holes running up the inside of both legs.
Ok, Audrey was rational and a big girl (in terms of age), she didn't need to sugar coat the fact that she had obviously chubbed up a little bit lately.
She could have happily gone without the sudden realisation that her thighs were rubbing together slightly more than usual though, the obvious culprit for her threadbare leggings.

I mean, it wasn't ENTIRELY her fault.
There had been plenty of times when she had cooked a meal for the house with full preparation for five portions only to not have all five girls appear at the table.

"Sorry Aud, boxercise class tonight!" announces Uma, passing through the hall with the stink of school gym already following her around.

"*Insert random boys name here* is taking me out tonight" cooes Phoebe as she skips out the door with her ass hanging out of god knows what.

"I'm streaming tonight, sorry Audrey" mutters Ixchel from her gaming throne in her room whilst ushering the resident matriach away.

"*Insert random boys name here* just broke up with me, I'm too sad to eat!" cries Phoebe not two days later.

You get the picture, Audrey lived with difficult to pin down individuals who couldn't respect a dinner schedule if it hit them in the face.
Lord only knows where Reagan was in all this, as the most rambunctious twin often just ghosted completely or acted like a child when asked a reasonable question.

Needless to say and, as one who hated to waste anything given the financial state of the household, Audrey found herself taking one for the team on a semi regular basis.
Seemed the majority of the time she was taking something for one team or another, but this particular situation dictated that Audrey served to make use of the excessive meals that she had lovingly prepared for the household.
This combined with her very sedent job and the tatters of her metabolism that had been ripped apart by stress as she had aged led to the sorry state the blonde found herself in now.

Lost in her own world, Audrey was completely unawares of the presence of Reagan behind her, observing her sisters exposed back caused by an up-riding top along with the chubby hips and rounded behind that adorned the blonde's bottom half.
"Woah there Aud, glad I realised it was you, was about to man a harpoon or something" sniggered the rowdy red head, making a very obvious snipe at her sisters weight.
Having had about enough, Audrey stood up from the basket she was knelt over, roughly tugged her currently stretched top down to cover herself and marched towards the door currently blocked by Reagan.

Seething as she passed the skinny red head, Audrey thought about giving the young lay about a piece of her mind but came to her senses a little before talking.
"Well seeing as you're so proactive how about you finish up the laundry?"
Leaving her sister dumbstruck in the doorway, Audrey couldn't help but smile to herself. She didn't often go full mum but sometimes it did have its perks.

"I can't do this, I'm seeing Sam in an hour!" shouted Reagan
"You dumped Sam" called back Audrey as she grabbed her coat and purse
"Damn it" muttered Reagan, not too subtly "well I'm meeting some friends in an hour"
"Well if you don't do the laundry you'll have to explain to them why you smell like an open sewer pipe" taunted Audrey as she opened the front door and stepped over the threshold
"That's so not fa..." started the fiery twin, losing ground quickly at this point.
"Bye Reagan!" shouted Audrey as she closed the door behind her.

Fuming herself, Reagan stroppily paced the hallway as her cousin appeared.
"Did Audrey just leave?" asked Ixchel, scratching her bare upper arm as she spoke
"Yeah" muttered Reagan, suddenly having an idea "hey, you understand technology right?"
"Not a chance Reagan, I heard Audrey" interjected Ixchel, before turning tail back to her room

Once again, left dumbstruck, Reagan wiped out her phone and hit up her bank.
Scrolling over the statement, a smile slowly formed on her lips
"Totally can buy a new outfit with that, problem solved" purred the red head, heading to the door herself.

"Phebs, Aud said do the laundry for her!" shouted Reagan up the stairs as she slammed the door behind her.
"Awww what?!" moaned the other twin, half way down the stairs
11114.title: Unfortunately for Audrey, her own clothes are s...

choices: Audrey can't resist the allure of the food court.
She sees some kitchen gadgets that might make cooking easier.
There's a new crisis at home when she returns.
Her new clothes don't last as long as she hoped.
111141.content:
Luckily for Audrey, a mall containing her favorite clothing outlet was only a fifteen minute drive from the townhouse. It was a hub for some of her essential purchases. After telling off Reagan, Audrey was feeling more keen overall despite her predicament. A slight weight flux aside, she had long been overdo for a new wardrobe. All she did for the townhouse and her flatmates regularly left her needs unfulfilled.

Once she made it to the Clothworth outlet, Audrey began to browse the racks for clothes that would look good. Somethings good, somethings practical, somethings that would look nice on her. Like date nice. Downright sexy even; a girl could dream.

After squirreling herself away with a haul to try on, Audrey found that she had misjudged just how much weight she had gained. It wasn't just age and fatigue that had ruined her clothes. Her first try-on options, from floral prints to cashmere, had only been selected one size larger that what was Audrey's usual size. Clearly, at the extent of that muffin top staring her back in the mirror as she tried on some teal shorts, she must had gone up two or three sizes.

"*sigh*" she groaned, "only the twins can pull it off." Few of her first picks survived the first try-on, greatly limiting Audrey's options as she went to return the clothes in order to find ones that actually fit her. Audrey's physique had always been big boned but there could be no further doubt that she had graduated to plus sizes. Her selection wasn't as large but there was still plenty of things Audrey found that suited her practical yet stylish interests.

It was a good thing none of the other girls were here, as any of Audrey's roommates would have provided commentary on the thin veneer splitting her 'mom/grandmother' fashion sense.

"Now this actually turned out," Audrey complimented her appearance with a jeans-blouse with a bit of embroidery that fit nicely over her plumped curves without pinching. And once she found a fitting sweater she sported quite the pair of sweater puppies. Her bra size must have increased too, although Audrey always felt embarrassed shopping for intimates.

Checking out with her new clothing purchases hurt Audrey's wallet more than she cared to admit. However, the experience left her feeling better now that she had a new wardrobe she could enjoy, as she took out four bags of clothes. Of course, she had made sure most of it was easily machine washable.

Still, she had some funds left over, which was handy considering...
111141.title: Drop What You Shop

choices: Audrey becomes obsessed with trying out new 'dining solutions.'
These 'healthy' cooking devices have more of the opposite effect.
Slowly, each resident of the townhouse finds a new gadget they like.
Can the townhouse budget really handle Audrey's new wardrobe and kitchen?
1111412.content:
It had been awhile since Audrey had gotten to shop on her own. She had to purchase things for the townhouse frequently as she inevitably ended up handling most of the finances and domestic needs. It had felt good to shop solely for herself and she had gotten a good deal out of it. The niggling insecurity of her frame filling out a couple clothing sizes was drowned out from the euphoria of responsible shopping.

Which was why, on the way out of the boutique, the speckled blonde was intrigued by the window sized posters adorning another storefront.

CLEARANCE SALE!!

ABSOLUTELY EVERYTHING MUST GO!!

LIQUIDATION VALUE!!

Audrey couldn't remember when the small appliance outlet had opened in the mall but clearly it was another sign of brick and mortar retailers losing out in the digital age. Call her more old fashioned than her generation suggested but Audrey valued being able to physically inspect her merchandise before spending money.

As she walked into the store to notice the inventory at slashed prices, her eyes immediately shot to a new toaster. The townhouse had an aged toaster that undercooked the toast. But this one could hold six slices and came in peach! When Audrey read the price tag her jaw hit the floor.

"That is a steal!" she whispered excitedly to herself, forgetting that the store was closing and directly advertised at the savings to be had. She couldn't let an opportunity like this slip her by. She had always wanted some of these cooking gadgets and the time to be saved would more than pay for their original value!

* * * * *


"Could somebody help me with the door?" Audrey called out, hours after she had left for the mall as she returned to 8422 Fordham Ave.

"I've got it," her cousin Ixchell said, opening the door only to have three boxes thrust into her hands.

"Daym, girl," Uma took in the scene, having enjoyed the quiet with Audrey out shopping and the twins both absent. "What is all this?"

"Oh good, you're here too Uma," Audrey remained oblivious of her roommates' reactions. "Can you carry this bag, they had to double bag it on account of the bulk."

"Where did you want," Ixchel asked, confused, as she read the boxes thrust into her hand. "A 'Mach Liquid' blender, a 'Bronzehead' pan and an omelette maker?"

"Just unpack them in the kitchenette," Audrey instructed.

Ixchel and Uma didn't know what to make of the haul Audrey had to pull from the car. This was the same frugal, practical minded blonde that had been doing the laundry that morning, right?

"I got such a good deal on all these!" Audrey said excitedly, preening as she showed off what she had purchased. "We can start cooking not only healthier but much quicker too!" One of her most prized purchases was the electric grill. "Remember when these were on infomercials all the time? I got it for less than the monthly installment price."

Uma eyed the machine critically. "For a 'Geoff Forgeman Grilling Machine'?"

Ixchel also looked at the box. "That doesn't sound right."

"Well, maybe it's not exactly the same," Audrey downplayed the concern, "but I cannot believe the savings to be had with that appliance store going out of business."

Uma checked the packing flyers. "Since when did the Garden Heights mall have an appliance store?"

"That's the thing, it just went out," Audrey hummed, arranging her new kitchen implements.

"Still," Ixchel scratched the back of her neck. "This seems like too much to get." Her own immediate family had numerous siblings, branches and generations living in close proximity. And while cuisine was a big part of their blended cultures, even that entire brood didn't need the amount of cookware Audrey had just splurged to get. There was only five of them in the townhouse.

"Come on, gals, this is for all of us. Look, Ixchel," Audrey thrust another box at her cousin. "A Smar-Tec basket steamer! With a built in timer and release in case you forget."

"Oh, that actually is useful," Ixchel marveled at the device, only to shrink back after noticing that Uma gave her a look that screamed 'Seriously?'

"Now who wants to help me test these out?" Audrey asked.

"Girl, we can barely all fit in the kitchenette as it is," Uma stated the obvious fact, as the three women were nearly crowded out of the room to make space for all the new appliances.

Audrey's smile turned cringeworthy for only a moment. "We'll make room! Somehow."
1111412.title: Blowout Sale!

choices: They can't deny it forever, as someone realizes the extent of their gain.
Audrey's appliances maintain ever-enlarging habits among the residents.
Much as they enjoyed eating from home, the others need a breakaway one night.
Laundry and shrunk clothes become the new drama at the townhouse.
11114122.content:
"This automatic pressure cooker and air-fryer micro-infuses flavor into the roast, so a little salt and seasoning goes a long way!" Audrey told her sisters when making dinner. The twin redheads were befuddled, although the house did smell good from the cooking.

"But what about the Taco Thursday night special at Aubelito's?" Phoebe asked, owing to a frequent townhouse tradition of getting tacos for dinner.

Audrey scoffed, "I didn't get the chance to overhaul our cookware and not test it out! Tell you what, while the roast is cooking we can use these freeze moulds for homemade sorbet or jello shapes for dessert."

Reagan sighed, although Phoebe was instantly on board the moment gelatin was mentioned.


"See, this side makes waffles while this side presses crepes!" Audrey explained eagerly at the start of breakfast the next day. "Using fresh fruit this make for a light and healthy meal, since I only use egg whites in the batter."

"You say that like it's a good thing," Uma said, eying her waffle suspiciously. "But that is the blanchest waffle I have ever seen. It's whiter than you!"

"Come on, give it a taste at least, Uma."

Th athlete bit her lip then took a forkful. "Huh," she chewed. "That's actually not too bad when you add syrup. Lemme try the other thing too, I need to carb load before my workout."

Audrey smiled, passing over the first crepe. "And the cider press I got can also be used to make syrup."

"You figure out how to make licorice syrup, Aud, and that might just pay for itself," Uma replied, far more appreciative of the new cookware.


"This roller case is just like the ones you see at the gas station," Audrey showed Ixchel before lunch. "But it's so versatile! We could sear burritos and keep corn on the cob warm too."

"Huh," Ixchel took a whiff of the cooking oil. "Is this Glip-Away not supposed to have a scent?"

"Hmm?" Audrey turned from where she was preparing a broiler. "Oh, Glip-Away is an imitation fat cooking oil. I got so many devices the store threw in 2 gallons worth of that stuff, it's from the same company as half of the new appliances."


Never before had Audrey shown such enthusiasm for cooking. It was normally a pain to get all the ladies in the townhouse to actually meet for dinner and not eat out constantly when that could cost a fortune. Few had ever appreciated Audrey's cooking in the past. However, over the next few weeks Audrey eventually won out each roommate to what these labor saving cookware devices could provide. Since most could be programmed for automatic cooking, Audrey no longer felt that cooking was a chore. It was actually kind of fun to try new things now that she had an array of kitchen gadgets. The other women of the house tapered off on eating out, so when Audrey and Ixchel were done with their jobs, Uma her workouts, and the twins with college, nights at 8422 Fordham Ave. was a veritable smorgasbord of as seen on TV options.

"I figured Audrey for a literal basket case once she got you this Smar-Tec basket steamer," Uma said over dinner one night when Ixchel had created the menu, "but these dumplings are killer!"

"The way my aunt taught me to make them was such a chore," Ixchel replied. "And these are done in a flash, ready to enjoy."

"Although some here have been enjoying it too much, ya think?" Uma said with a wry smile.

"What?" Ixchel was confused be the statement, although a brief scrutiny of Uma's posture led her to believe it was a projective statement. "Indeed, I guess some of us have."

Each woman was critical of how pudgy the other was getting while oblivious to their newfound plumpness. Uma noticed that Ixchel, always on the chubby side since she had known her, had put on a few since Audrey had been cooking up a storm with her clearance sale appliances. Overall she looked more doughy from breast to stomach, the most telling change being under the hem of her skirt. Her pillowy thighs spread out over her seat, notably thicker than normal.

Ixchel, meanwhile, noticed that Uma didn't look the stellar picture of fitness currently. All of this 'carb-loading' had left the black, hedonistic athlete with a hint of a gut. Fat was having trouble finding a place to settle on Uma's toned frame, most of it settling around her middle to add a small roll to her zip-up jersey. It remained Ixchel of when she and Audrey had tried for swim team a few summers when they were kids. Some of the girls were bigger like them, husky athletes, although Uma was getting rather husky if she kept up this diet.

"Yeah, someone really likes Audrey's cooking," Uma replied back.

"It must help those that are getting, what's the term," Ixchel teased, "bulked up before they get cut and ripped?"

"Huh?" Uma asked, half a dumpling in her mouth.

"Hey, you too better not be hogging all the dumplings," Reagan said as she came back for seconds.

"Quite you're whining, Red," Uma said with mild scorn. "Audrey and Ixchel can make more if we run out."

"Gosh, these are tasty!" Phoebe said as she too refilled her plate, while Reagan was making sideways glances at the other housemates.

"Psst, sis" Reagan whispered. "Check out tubby and chunky."

"Who?" Phoebe asked, loudly.

"Sssh," Regan chided, softly telling her twin to look towards where Uma and Ixchel sat in the breakfast nook. Once Phoebe noticed what Regan indicated they shared a private giggle as they made their way back to eat in front of the TV.

"Uma and Chel were looking so porky!" Phoebe whispered.

"Yeah," Regan snickered. "Keep it up and they'll be a pair of butterballs."

"You'd tell me if I was getting fat, right Regan?"

"Ehh, probably," Reagan replied, content in savoring the taste of the dumplings. It would be funny to tease her younger twin about plumping up.

The twins looked to have stayed the skinniest in this whole endeavor. However, while their stomachs remained flat there was a particular feature the two shared tailor made to store excess calories. Both Reagan and Phoebe were looking packed in the back of their jeans, each of their rears getting outrageously bodacious. As the Durant twins favored their best asset, any signs of weight gain were clouded by the usual feeling of tightness whenever their butts would grow more shapely.

Regan, eventually, had to adjust her sitting to try and dig at where her thong was biting into her fleshy ass cheeks. "I swear, Audrey may have gotten a handicap at cooking but she's lousing up my laundry!"

"Yeah, it's really itchy," Phoebe replied, as she tugged at her bra which felt tighter than she had remembered. It was a subtle difference between the two pear shaped twins, but Regan had definitely filled out her butt more than Phoebe had, as the younger twin had some of her newly acquired fat settling in her chest. And these dumplings they gorged on would only add to this predicament.

Still, the four housemates might poke fun at who had plumped up the most while remaining oblivious to their own, but each of them would agree that there was one person with the most signs of loving Audrey's cooking.

Audrey herself.

"I'm glad everyone has been enjoying these dinners at home," Audrey said, after getting another plate. "These appliances help with eating healthy. I think my weight is going to turn around."

The twins, who had the first look of Audrey sitting down, had to stifle another snicker.

Audrey was looking more jovial and upbeat than she had for ages, but 'slimming down' was not the word any of her housemates would use to describe her. Perennially the biggest boned of the bunch, Audrey was an apple shape that was looking more juicy than it had any right to be. She had yet to grow out of her clothes but they were looking tight. Audrey would taste everything she cooked as she tested each new device and the results were obvious to all but herself, apparently.

That was catching in this townhouse.

Indeed, Audrey now had a noticeable bulge to her belly at all times, even between meals, and her chest and backside were looking extra weighty. Her face looked a bit fuller as well. No double chin or love handles just yet, although for the more sardonically minded of the house they figured that would come in time with Audrey's shift in lifestyle.

"What's Audrey talking about?" Ixchel asked in the kitchen.

Uma leaned to look out into the living room. "About how good this 'eating healthy' is doing for her. Helping her gain more than a few, it looks like."

"Yeah," Ixchel said with lost irony. "She's in denial as much as the twins are with their bigger booties."

"That's only because they make it look good," Uma said, absentmindedly scratching herself around her new plushness.
11114122.title: Fubsy, Mean, Fat-Inducing Cooking Machines

choices: Budget cuts make for an unhealthy stocked kitchen
Everyone stays in a lot more doing chores
1111413.content:
Clothes in hand and a smile on her face, Audrey felt surprisingly upbeat despite her usual outlook on life as a single mother of four grown up children.
She'd even managed to stretch to one of her personal favourites, a sweet pretzel, from the food court.
Things were going well and the blonde didn't even care that she'd gone up in size more than she'd hope.

The calm serenity washing over Audrey was quickly shattered, however, as her phone angrily buzzed inside her bag.
"I wonder what this could be" asked Audrey of herself, foolish naivety clouding her judgement just enough to forget this was probably a disaster.
And what a disaster it was.
"Oh no" muttered Audrey as she shoved her phone back into her bag after reading the panicked message from Phoebe begging for her to come home.

"Not even an afternoon to myself" grumbled the blonde as she marched off to deal with the next problem.

**********

"Oh my god!" shouted Audrey as she stood at the top of the stairs to the basement, looking down at what could now only be described as a swimming pool "what happened?!"
Trying to not lose her cool as she looked at Phoebe, Audrey slowly made her way down the stairs to get a closer look.

"I don't know!" howled Phoebe as she stood ankle deep in water pouring out of the washing machine from all sides, as the tears slowly rolled down her cheeks having smudged her mascara.

"Ok, lets just calm down" assured Audrey despite her anger, gently cuddling her youngest sister without stepping into the standing water "why did you stay down here when its clearly flooding?"

"I don't know" sniffed Phoebe "I just thought it would be best if I..."
And so the tears came afresh as Phoebe rather pathetically nuzzled against Audrey

"Right, go upstairs and get yourself changed because you're going to catch a cold if you stay in those damp clothes much longer"
Audrey didn't dare ask why Phoebe was completely drenched when the water was only a few inches deep, the more ditzy twin had a tendency of causing anarchy where ever she went, albeit less maliciously than her twin Reagan.

Reagan...

"Hey Phebes honey?" called Audrey before the redhead could escape the basement completely.

"Yeah?" sniffed Phoebe as she looked back down, looking like a deer in the headlights ready to be mowed down

"Where's Reagan?" asked Audrey flatly, realising all too well that Reagan had no doubt skipped out on helping just for a change

"She, erm, went out I guess?" replied Phoebe, looking confused "she said you wanted me to do the laundry"

Audrey shook her head, mostly to herself, before returning to address Phoebe.
"Ok, thanks for trying sweetie" smiled Audrey, trying to be as sincere as possible

"No problem!" chirped Phoebe, nearly all remnants of panic disappearing almost instantly as she walked off to get changed, a trail of water marking her route.

This left Audrey stood in the basement, completely aghast at the situation before her.
It was beyond her understanding how Phoebe had managed to mess up the laundry so much, the machine had been deliberately picked for its simplicity on the off chance any of the other girls decided to contribute to the weekly chores.
More so though, she was fuming at Reagan.
It wasn't a difficult request, 'do some laundry Reagan', and yet here Audrey was, picking up from the fallout of yet another Reagan class nuclear fallout.

With her hands on her hips and sighing deeply, Audrey rolled her sleeves and trousers up before heading down the stairs and taking a proper look at the now defunct washing machine.
Unsure of where to start, Audrey became quietly aware of the sound of shopping bags rubbing past each other, and, in the nick of time, managed to turn to see one bag fall from the step she had left it on and into the pooling water below.
Sighing again, Audrey couldn't tear her eyes away as the blouse she had chosen so fondly slowly floated out of its plastic holder and made headway towards an opposing corner of the basement.
"Yep, sounds about right" grumbled Audrey as she turned back to the washing machine.

***********

"Thanks Uma for the help" smiled Audrey as she stepped to one side as her college friend delivered the last push to place the dead washing machine at the top of the basement stairs and into the hallway.

"Don't mention it Aud, I won't need to hit the gym after that" smirked the athlete, giving the machine a resounding slap as if to claim victory.

Audrey laughed as she wiped her hands "well, all the same"

As the two friends chuckled over their success, the front door flew open, crashing into the wall revealing the not so delicate door opener

"Sup bitches!" called out Reagan as she lent against the doorframe whilst stretching herself to exhibit her new outfit to a less than enthusiastic audience.

"Jeez, I hope the guys respond better than that otherwise I'm taking this shit back" grumbled the fiery redhead as she stepped into the hallway whilst casually kicking the door closed behind her

"Well I hope you didn't pay much considering how much of it there isn't" spat Uma, equally unimpressed the with the older twin having had the run down from Audrey as they worked out what to do about the washing machine.

"You bet there isn't much" teased Reagan with a wink.

The outfit in question was indeed Reagan's taste.
Comprising of a pair of fishnet stockings alongside a pair of red denim booty shorts cut so high a sizable bulge of ass cheek was hanging out of each leg, Reagan was all for exhibiting her best features.
Her top didn't go amiss in this arrangement, mind, and the redhead had settled for a far from concealing boob tube that barely sat under her boobs whilst a little warmth was brought by a thin leather jacket around her shoulders.

"I hope you're happy" asserted Audrey as she placed herself before her sister, arms folded.

"Generally, yes" mused Reagan, amusing herself more than anyone else.

"Well you shouldn't be" continued Audrey "I ask you to do a simple task and instead you disappear and leave your sister to do it?"

"She was fine with it, besides..." started Reagan before finding her feet dangling off the ground.

"Woah, what the hell!" screamed the redhead as Uma lifted her and carried her down the basement stairs, sitting her on the first step before the water

Her initial rage fading, Reagan started to laugh as she looked at the mess before her
"Jeez, has baby twin started wetting herself again?" chuckled the redhead as she looked behind her

"Hey!" shouted Phoebe who had returned after hearing her name and was now stood at the top of the stairs, toweling her hair as she stood in her less than dignified pyjamas.

Before an argument could ensue, Audrey cut through to the forefront.
"There's got to be some changes round here, I can't support this place on my own any more and things like THIS can't happen every time I trust one of you to do a job"
Silence fell over the other three girls present as the looked around awkwardly, knowing full well they were main culprits there.

"Nothing to say?" asked Audrey as she surveyed the group.
Still silence
"Good. House meeting, five minutes" asserted the blonde as she walked out of the basement, sliding past Phoebe as she did.

With noone knowing what to say, the three girls all looked at each other slightly dumbfound before one of them finally broke the silence.

"Well lucky me bought these sweet clothes before the dictatorship kicked in" chuckled Reagan as she admired herself once again as she stood up to leave the basement.

"Oh shut up" muttered Uma before neatly nudging the redhead ever so slightly as she was midstep.

Needless to say, Uma and Phoebe ran like hell before a large splash rang through the house indicating the swift baptism of Reagan's new outfit.
1111413.title: Townhouse drowning

choices: Surfing online, Reagan finds a special offer.
Impersonate her sister Phoebe to set up a prank.
Sabotage one of her roommate’s diets.
Check out a cool new restaurant that just opened up.
Regan can’t find anything to do, which drives everyone crazy.
12.content:
Reagan Durant was bored. It was dangerous when Reagan got bored.

Reagan was twenty-two and everything was going for her. She lived with her sisters and roommates in this townhouse. She had worked out a major score of a deal with her sister, Audrey, who got a student rental discount on account of Reagan and her goofy twin Phoebe attending the same campus as the landlord had, who was an alumnus. Reagan had twisted the deal further to wiggle out of paying rent, saving her dollars for the important stuff.

It wasn’t tuition.

While Reagan kept up on tuition more or less every other penny of her college fun went to her own amusement. Reagan was too clever for her own good, always scheming. She also had a smoking hot body, a fine white girl booty and killer looks. If only she didn’t have the genetic clone of a twin sister.

Reagan knew she had everything going for her and took to finding every advantage in life. She was just brilliant enough to keep up that life of laziness. It helped that there were five of the girls in this townhouse. Plenty of others to drop off all the chores and shit Reagan didn’t want to do.

Sadly everyone who had lived with her this long were immune to the twin swap trick. Even if Phoebe had classes for acting Reagan easily considered herself the better actor, the amount of times she pretended to be her sister to get out of trouble or shift the blame. Nobody in the townhouse fell for it anymore, as they had picked up on the subtle cues that identified each twin, given their opposite personalities.

Still, leading Phoebe around was easy because she was such a sheep. Leave things alone long enough and either Audrey or Ixchel would handle it for her. On occasion Reagan had even swindled Uma Ferro to do something for her. That didn’t happen too often given that the black athlete, Audrey’s college roommate, was cut from the same cloth as Reagan when it came to shirking duty. The two had hit it off after that. Hell, Uma tended to be the only roommate Reagan could stand living with.

It was a typical Saturday morning at the townhouse. Reagan didn’t have any plans although there’s plenty should have been doing. Her acoustical engineering professor was riding her double fine ass (metaphorically speaking) on a major project but Reagan didn’t feel like sinking long hours at the campus on a Saturday.

It was getting kind of stuffy in the townhouse. Noisy too. Not the kind of noise Reagan liked. The drone was filled with Phoebe’s mindless television, Ixchel’s vapid K-Pop, the sounds of Uma’s workouts and Audrey’s continued frustrated ranting. Reagan didn’t want to stick around but she also didn’t want to get up that early on Saturdays to get out of the townhouse before all the monotony happened.

She needed something to do fast or the whole day was going to be super annoying.
12.title: Reagan Durant

choices: A lifetime supply of her favorite toaster pastries! There’s just one catch.
Someone needed a house sitter while they were on vacation.
Healthy people for medical testing? Tremendous compensation!
A family clinic paying big dollars to surrogate mothers.
121.content:
Fuming at the slow loading speed when she had fired up the browser on her tablet, Reagan got herself up from the nook she had carved out for herself in what was turning out to be an aimless day for the residents of 8422 Fordham Ave. The silly reality tv trash that Phoebe loved and Audrey tolerated echoed up from the bottom floor as Reagan crossed to Ixchel’s office.

“Yo! Chel! What’s the password?”

“Huh?” The dark, moon shaped face of her multiracial cousin poked up from behind the door of her little office. Her hair looked matted.

“What’s the wifi password?”

“I copied it onto the noteboard by the fridge to stop Phoebe from asking,” Ixchel replied.

“No, your password! The shitty wifi on the block is slow as hell because everyone is online at the same time this weekend.”

The doughy programmer frowned. “I need to keep the dedicated wifi protected for work.”

“Bullshit!” Reagan grilled her. “You’ve got plenty of connection speed for livestreams every other night and not a digit of your med-tech data is out of place! Come on, just let me on for an hour.”

Ixchel sighed. “Fine.” She wrote out the password for Reagan, making a mental note to change it again.

“Was that so hard?” Regan asked herself ten minutes later, after returning to her retreat up on the third floor with two Dr. Peppers an a can of Pringles, snacks for some mindless surfing. There was plenty of cheap junk in the house that Reagan had gained a taste for.

Damn, everybody annoyed her now! Why couldn't she and Ixchel or Uma do something fun, like play some video games or catch a movie? Everybody retreated to do their own little thing and if you asked Audrey to do anything she came up with a list of chores. Everybody was so non-comittial.

While there had been a show she wanted to torrent online Reagan couldn’t remember the site, so she drifted through various sites in hopes of finding someing to catch her attention before she had to get up again.

While she had conned Audrey to get off her back enough about rent life in the townhouse was the pits. Sure, she was shackled with her sisters but Reagan had thought living together would be awesome. They could do whatever they wanted after classes. Only Audrey had become such a hard nose and Ixchel kept odd hours, secluding herself away in the office. Uma was fun but she didn’t invite Reagan to all the same parties as her after Audrey reminded her that Reagan still needed to finish her degree.

Which she still had two years of credits left to finish. Hell, how come Reagan couldn’t score some easy cash right now? She could get her own place, hang out with her choice of friends that preferred her company and become the center of attention again. She scratched her redheaded scalp in frustration.

And that’s when, aimlessly browsing the web, Reagan came across a special offer.
121.title: Surfing for Deals

choices: Enter a lottery; more proofs of purchase, more chances to win!
Find an elusive, prizewinning platinum ticket hidden within an unknown packet.
Design a new flavor that the manufacturer will add to the Toppin' Tarts menu.
1211.content:
Reagan was chewing on some Pringles, making that two-crisp duck bill that everybody has done at one point or another, when she nearly choked on the imitation chips.

"Lifetime supply of Toppin' Tarts!!" Reagan swallowed, sitting up from the nest she had made for herself out of a laundry pile.

Shit! Toppin' Tarts was her jam ever since she was a kid. The toaster pastries weren't as mainstream as the more common Pop Tarts but they had grown in popularity over the years. They were the first to advertise as "Enjoy Them Frozen" and there was also a sub-brand that had a jelly filled flakey crust with optional frosting kinda like Toaster Strudels.

When she was young, her parents found Toppin' Tarts to be a cheap and frequent kids breakfast option. The twins could be sustained by splitting a pack in half which had always bothered Reagan even when she was small. Why did she always have to share with her twin when Audrey could have both tarts from her pack all on her own?

So as a kid Reagan frequently scammed her parents or her sister out of Toppin' Tart shares. As a teen she'd spend most of her allowance and other cash she would scrounge together on her stash of Toppin' Tarts. She could sit on her ass and never tire of eating Toppin' Tarts all day. Hell, that's likely part of the reason she got such a killer ass to begin with; Reagan had shed her awkward chubby phase after middle school by losing the pounds save those stored in her bodacious behind.

Reagan's mouth was watering at the thought of her favorite Toppin' Tart flavors. Cinnamon Crunch, Triple Berry, Ice Cream Smoothie, Peach Marmalade, Chocolate Chip Muffin...

Back when she was living in the dorms Reagan almost lived off the things. Although during the move to the townhouse Audrey had initially thrown out all of the junk food in the thought that everyone might follow Ixchel's example and try to eat healthier. Never mind that Ixchel had more or less been outset all her life and Audrey finally broke down after realizing how expensive it would be to go organic.

But now, if Reagan could win this contest she would have a lifetime supply of her favorite toaster pastries. Audrey couldn't argue with free! And Reagan wouldn't have to share any with her sisters!

Her vindictive grin to right wrongs from childhood became a crestfallen look as she continued to read on about the lifetime supply contest. Typical marketers, dragging people in with a bold statement that belied all the fine print and particulars.

If Reagan wanted to be waist deep in a steady supply of her favorite pastries, she would have to...
1211.title: Reading the Fine Print

choices: Unfortunately, Reagan isn’t a viable surrogate.
A couple selects Regan to have their baby.
The doctor has an unusual proposition for Reagan.
Regan loses her nerve, and tries to convince Phoebe to take her place.
1214.content:
Like any deep web session, Reagan found herself down a rabbit hole of various web searches completely different from where she initially was going to torrent movies. She had been looking up various quick rich schemes and found herself clicking on something she normally wouldn’t have done.

“Gosh, you can be paid that much?” Reagan mused, looking at the kickbacks for blood plasma donations. Being sucked dry with needles didn’t fancy her, even if she got some dough out of it. After looking through some related medical donations or studies, she came across a link at the bottom of the page.

“Surrogacy?” As in, carrying a baby to term for another couple. Being someone else’s baby momma? Sure, Reagan was plenty promiscuous and had an active sex life, although she didn’t see having a baby in her cards. To lose her rockin’ bod to baby weight? No thank you.

On a lark, she decided to click it anyway to get a good laugh. And then nearly spit out her Dr. Pepper as her eyes read the new web page.

“Forty to fifty thousand in benefits?!” Reagan swallowed her soda, her eyes darting fervently as she looked at terms and dollar signs. Comfortably getting a half-grand package plus other benefits to carry somebody’s kid to full term; would she be willing to give up so much of her life to get that kind of cash?

Reagan considered where her life currently was at, shirking her college studies and hiding out in this dinky townhouse she had to share with four other people. And this could pay out almost as cushy as an office job, with clients with deep pockets at a surrogacy clinic two cities over.

Still, it was a radical decision to make. As much as the cash was attractive to Reagan, the implications were one that needed to be considered with sound, rational judgement.

Pringles and Dr. Pepper wouldn’t cut it anymore. Reagan needed brain food.

Leaving her hidey hole, unfortunately, made Reagan susceptible to the trash TV watched by her younger twin and older sister. They were in deep on an episode of The Shoal, one of those east coast reality show types about trendy rich people.

“Hey Reagan, come watch with us,” Phoebe offered to her twin.

“I can’t believe you actually watch this...stuff…” Reagan trailed off, bemused by what she saw on the TV. “Who is that?”

“Gigi?” Audrey replied, as the camera zoomed in on an expectant looking woman and her entourage. “Runs some line of makeup, tries to be a trendsetter, really hates her life coach.”

Phoebe provided commentary over this Gigi heading to her salon, with every employee in the shop focused on her service. “And ever since she got pregnant everyone’s been treating her like a queen! But she actually hasn’t revealed who the father is yet, which really upsets her brother and co-partner.”

“It has to be Luca,” Audrey said. “But she must be holding back the news to keep him from leaving.”

“But she had that fling with her tennis instructor,” Phoebe said, “so nobody really knows--Reagan?” The redhead turned but her twin was gone. “Where’d she go?”

“Hopefully she’s not out doing anything foolish,” Audrey said, cursing the untimely buzz of the dryer from the basement as some juicy gossip was dropping.


Now, Reagan didn’t necessarily make a foolish decision, but her seeking out the surrogacy clinic wasn’t a decision she had made solely for altruistic reasons. The promise of tremendous compensation, plus the idea she could garner lots of attention from playing the preggo card, were prime motivators for the bodacious redhead wanting to stand out from her twin and family.

Although it involved more effort than she had expected, forms to fill out, interviews to be had, medical tests to meet. There were some costs for her up front, which Reagan had weasled together with the theory that becoming a surrogate would more than make up for it.

Being a single, college-aged student without any previous births made her an unlikely candidate, information a nurse had told her early in the process, although Regan had schmoozed her way through the system given the positive results of her medical history. She was healthy, had never done hard drugs, could reduce her alcohol intake, was at the ideal weight for her age and in the prime of her fertility, although it wouldn’t be her eggs used in the process. In the meantime of this application process, Reagan focused back on college to look good for the paperwork, all to justify her history and increase her chances as she completed the rigorous process.

Many weeks later, after full evaluation and both her psychological and background checks cleared, Regan was contacted to come to the clinic to discuss her options. The good news Regan was hoping for, as her schemes reached a new stage.
1214.title: Suroga-Crazy

choices: Having not told her roommates, Reagan tries to downplay her growing body.
Coming clean about her surrogacy doesn't led to the reactions she had expected.
Morning sickness, cravings, and belly growth all hit heavily carrying multiples.
In an odd twist, Reagan isn't the only townhouse resident that's pregnant.
12143.content:
“Miss Durant, thank you for coming so soon,” said Dr. Schnieder, a grey haired, balding man who was one of the directors of the clinic. “My associate, Dr. Caulapa, said you were very responsive during your clinical checkup.”

“Yes, well, it’s a tremendous opportunity,” Regan said, crossing her legs as she sat down. Her aim was to play up her more positive qualities, having undergone much scrutiny.

“Normally, you would not be her first choice,” Dr. Schnieder continued, “as we usually look to married women who have a dedicated family structure, and you have not previously had a birth. But your medical history aligns with an interesting proposition, which is why I have vouched for you to begin surrogacy so soon. Since you are a twin.”

Reagan smiled, although she was somewhat confused. “Yes?”

“And your family has a history of multiples, correct?”

“Yes, both our grandmothers were twins, along with some twin great-uncles. And if you go far back enough there’s triplets.” Regan was beginning to wonder if she was getting in over her head.

“And without me being too bold, Miss Durant, you have quite the pair of child bearing hips.”

The doctor didn’t sound lecherous, although Reagan appreciated the flattery for her body. “Where exactly is this going, doctor?”

Dr. Schnieder opened a file. “It used to be a common practice that multiple viable embryos were transferred into a surrogate. It wasn’t always the case that each would begin gestating. Although there are some who are interested in having multiples from a surrogacy, and in my studies a woman with a family lineage of multiple births will have a better chance at carrying the babies to term, even if her eggs are not used. Are you aware of the diAngelos?”

Reagan was taken aback. “Should I be?”

“Julian and Margaret diAngelo. Media moguls, they run several charitable foundations but they have always dreamed of having their own family. Margaret has been unable to bear children, however they are quite insist on having their own children rather than adoption with a suggested agency”

Reagan had been planning for this exact moment, although the prospect of carrying what, two(?), three babies(?) was a daunting one. She might almost break her cover story.

“There is, of course, additional financial compensation to you for the stresses of a multiple birth,” Dr. Schneider said.

More babies, more money?

Reagan had come this far, and at that moment she had decided to take the plunge. “I’ll do it.”

More scheduling and procedures followed this monumental decision, including Reagan meeting the couple and starting a regimen of prenatal vitamins. And holy smokes the diAngelos were loaded! They dressed fancy, took Reagan out to dinner at a steakhouse to discuss options, and were very supportive and excited about the prospects. If Reagan had been doubting her objective until now, knowing that the parents in this endeavor had deep pockets stymied what concerns she had about such a tremendous undertaking.

And changes soon occurred for Reagan as her schemes hit a snag:
12143.title: The diAngelo Multiplication

choices: Audrey—it's not like it's that hard to mess with her anyway...
Phoebe—it's about time they became a lot less identical
Ixchel—more like Double-Ex-Chel, am I right?
Uma—Or should we start calling her Double-Uma?
123.content:
Okay, listen. I know what you're thinking.

But there's a perfectly logical explanation as to how she came to the idea (at least, reasons logical enough to Reagan) that help smooth this out narratively. Even though she'd always been the Gadfly amongst her housemates, Reagan wasn't exactly the type of person to go around sabotaging peoples' diets. Normally!

But it had been a weird couple of days.

Almost all anyone seemed to talk about was weight, one way or the other. Really, you could blame Audrey for that. Her penchant for stress snacking meant that she had been especially squirrely in the kitchen these days. With four other roommates (namely Reagan, but that was neither here nor there!) to play den mother to, her pants had gotten a little tighter before she realized just what was going on, and it had become her new obsession ever since - a new health kick that had brought everyone else's figures to the forefront of their minds.

For the past week, Audrey had been making self-deprecating jokes, avoiding sweets, and doing these obnoxious clenches that made her look like she was holding something in. Naturally Uma had been one to offer to help her exercise, while also coming to her friend's defense.

"You think I haven't put on a few lately - all that beer's gotta go somewhere..." she'd said at least once or twice this week, with a slap to her still flat belly, "What's say we go on a run and help me trim my extra pounds and inches?"

Of course, neither had yet to actually go on that run. But the point remained, the two of them got stuck on the subject. Which meant that Phoebe, obvi, was going to catch up on it to.

"Do I look bloated, Rae?" Phoebe had asked about a billion times, "I feel bloated."

"Oh my God, if you ask me that one more time I'm going to fucking kill you." Raegan groaned, had clawed dramatically at her face in utter agony of the banality of her twin's question, "You look great, stop fucking askinggggggggg."

Lastly that left cousin Chel, perhaps the only person in the house who was qualified to worry about her weight, to her own devices. Since Raegan and Phoebe were talking about it, and everyone else was talking about it, Ixchel had decided to give up soda in hopes of shedding some pounds and inches. Having always been a little chubby, Raegan doubted that would have done her much good. But cousins were cousins after all.

"If we could hook you up to a treadmill powered PC, I bet you'd be able to game AND lose weight."

Ixchel had snorted at that, before taking a swig of her "one" soda of the day. She hadn't wanted to quit cold turkey, but she also hadn't been really good about giving up sugary carbonated beverages in general. When she wasn't swigging soda, she was usually snacking. So Raegan had her doubts about how well any diet would go for her...

Anyway, so it had been a weird week in the house.

Everyone was diet crazy except for Raegan, and she was bored.

As the resident troublemaker of the group... it almost felt like an obligation for her to fuck with one of her housemates' aspirations of slimming down, didn't it?

The only question was... who was going to be in Raegan's sights?
123.title: Listen up Y'all, it's a Sabotage

choices: Over the next several days, secret sabotages make Uma look puffy.
Reagan combines her efforts with appeals to Uma's hedonistic partying tendency.
Uma suspects something is up after finding she's gaining fat, not muscle.
Another housemate gets targeted on top of the combat of Uma's diet.
1234.content:
Much as everyone's recent diet kick was super annoying for Reagan, the woman to push things over the top became Uma. As the resident athlete since her high school days, short of having the full dedication to go pro, Uma considered matters of fitness her expertise. And holy heck would should not shut up about recommended workout tips.

"See, ya gotta stretch out those glutes before you go on a run, even for the treadmill." Advice given to Audrey.

"Do you know how many minutes of cardio it takes to burn off those calories?" After catching Ixchel eating some leftover spare ribs before dinner.

"You've got to hydrate and sweat if you have any hopes of shedding those pounds, so skip the probiotics." Phoebe being told off of her favorite yogurt brand.

"The thighs tend to chunk up first, so rotate through sets of squats and lunges," Uma caught Reagan by surprise, giving her upper legs a poke.

"Hey, hands off! I'm not getting fat." Reagan protested.

Uma cracked a smile of gleaming white teeth. "Ya sure? You and Phebes are looking too porky in the bottoms." Uma gave Reagan's fine buttocks a sporting slap on her way to fish a gatorade out of the fridge.

Insulted, Reagan shot back. "So what, jealous?"

"Hardly, Rae. But if you want muscle tone like mine, and I could go with shedding some up top, we need to sign you up for some high intensity mixed weight workouts."

"OhMyGodJustShutUp," Reagan mouthed under her breath, incredulous at Uma's claims. What weight did she need to lose? The lively, African American athlete was voluptuous in a stocky way, thick with muscle tone and eager to show off her fit bod with midriff revealing sportsware she wore around the house. And since the topic of weight woes had permeated the townhouse, she had been insufferable lording her fitness over everybody else. This was the same Uma who, weeks prior, was chill with Friday night wings & booze, three plates at the buffet and overing double at the drive thru.

And her metabolism didn't look to have changed, prime athletic efficiency able to consume and burn a lot of calories for her physical efforts. The way Uma considered herself better than everyone else in the house in weight loss matters made Reagan sick, as the older of the twins did not feel the need to lose weight in the slightest.

"So what, aren't there a lot of sugars in those things?" Reagan latched onto the gatorade for the slightest attempt at critiquing Uma's habits.

"The energy and electrolytes given in my game fuel replenish what I need from a serious workout," Uma replied, moving to emphasis her trim figure. "I'm just saying you should watch out for flab, Red. You and Phoebe may have the best butts in the house, but can you truly flex?"

After striking another pose, Uma's hearty cheeks flexed twice on her backside within her basketball shorts. Combined with patting her bulged bicep, Uma shot Reagan some finger guns as she left the kitchenette. "Call me up when you want to lose a few of those inches."

Reagan was left seeing red after that. How could Uma get off claiming they should all lose some fat when she had the lowest body fat percentage of any of them? And she still ate like a horse. Previously, before these unwanted dieting tips became insufferable, Uma had told Reagan that her main stratagems for her fitness regimen followed the principle of "Bulk Up, Get Cut."

As in, load up on plenty of proteins and calories before the workout, then focus on exercise to turn increasing mass into muscle. Reagan was smart enough to realize that there was a thin line in that methodology that could lead to flab rather than fab.

So she now had a target.


Hours later, Reagan made her way back home with shopping bags dedicated to her efforts to sabotage Uma's workouts. The health goods, hardware and grocery stores had been hit up in sequence. Reagan serruptiously entered the house, cautious to not get caught by Uma.

"Hey Reagan, where have you been?" Phoebe suddenly popped up to greet her.

"Jesus! Damnit sis," Reagan shushed her twin. "Keep it down."

"Why are we whispering?" Phoebe whispered, trying to peek into the bags.

"It's for a project at school," Reagan replied, trying to change the subject. The last thing she needed was Phoebe blabbing on her scheme. "Why don't you go watch that TV show you like with Audrey so much?"

"Can't. She, Chel and Uma went to sign up for yoga classes."

That was an unexpected opportunity to get her scheme underway while her target was out of the house. "Sweet! Uh, I mean, why aren't you with them, then?"

"I haven't been feeling as bloated since I switched off the probiotics," Phoebe explained. "So I didn't want to jump back into it until they tell me there's probiotics in the class."

Reagan paused, setting down her bags on the counter. "Wait, what do you think they're doing at yoga classes?"

Phoebe shrugged. "Dunno, making healthy yogurt parfaits? Sure, I like 'em but signing up for a whole class about making it seems boring."

Holy shit, could her twin be a brain-dead dolt sometimes. "Whatever. So, do you want to help me assemble an amplifier for my thesis project?"

The question was itself a ploy, as Phoebe tended to go cross eyed whenever Reagan went into the specifics of her acoustical engineering degree. While Reagan had yet to become a major music producer, roadie or DJ from her coursework, it provided the perfect excuse to get unwanted attention from her back. Reagan retreated to her room, grinning wickedly as she took stock of her arsenal.

"Time to have double up Uma double her weight," Reagan snickered, with big plans to have Uma chunk up in size. Taking out a woman in the prime of her fitness felt like the ultimate scheme, and Reagan had gathered materials to prepare for that effort.

It would start simple, having found some vitamin shop products dangerous for the waistline if used in the wrong combination. Uma always touted a specific brand of whey protein powder for her muscle shakes. The cheaper brand, with a more crude formula, had less nutritional value. That would be followed by dissolvable appetite stimulant tablets and almost tasteless water retaining salt.

Reagan would combine this was a two pronged approach on Uma's favorite vittles; a range of her guilty pleasure favorite snacks, along with the full-fat, all-calorie, sugar-added versions of her health food junk.

As for the tools: How else was Uma's exercise bike going to have an ill timed bolt on the wheel? Or a controlled short on the treadmill?

"She's not going to know what hit her," Reagan rubbed her hands together, picturing triumph as Uma started putting on the pounds.
1234.title: From Cut to Chunk

choices: Reagan puts in the leg work, continuing to sneak around behind Uma's back
Reagan puts in some face time, offering to take Uma out to eat more regularly
12341.content:
Things like this didn't happen overnight.

It was hard for Reagan to remember that, sometimes, the best-laid plans were the ones that took the longest to pay off. After all, she was no stranger to instant gratification. But this wasn't just changing out shampoo or tickling someone with whipped cream in their hand while they were asleep. Uma was an absolute fitness nut, and getting her to start slipping wasn't going to be an easy task. It was going to take time and effort to get her on the train to chunkytown, which were two things that Reagan usually did her best to steer clear from...

But in this case, she was willing to make an exception.

"Hey Audrey, can I borrow you for a second?"

It hadn't been the first time that Uma had started her day on the NordicTrack. Currently unemployed and coasting along on Audrey's good will, she didn't have much of a reason not to begin her days as she saw fit. And normally, she often saw fit to get off on the right foot with some light exercises.

Today, it looked like she was going to have to make a few adjustments to her schedule.

"No one's been fucking with my track, right?"

Reagan could hear the conversation well enough from her deceptively aloof position sprawled out on her bed. Uma's room wasn't too far away from her own, and she wasn't exactly a low talker. One airpod in and the other out, she angled her head to get a better reception on what was being said—the wicked thrill of a job well done tickling her into a small but wicked smile.

"I don't think so." Audrey's voice was as diplomatic as ever in a house where accusations could (admittedly) get thrown around wildly, "At least, none of us have used it. We know the rule about touching your stuff."

"Are you sure? I know everyone's been trying to lose a little weight lately..."

"I'm pretty sure, Uma, but I can ask..." an awkward pause in the conversation, one that made Reagan itch the bridge of her nose in anticipation, "...why do you ask?"

"Because it just gave out on me all of the sudden—" a whack that Reagan recognized as the hard plastic casing of Uma's NordicTrack, "—I bought this thing, like, a month after I moved in here. It's practically brand new!"

Reagan giggled maliciously to herself. It was brand new.
